thread.title: Halloween stories, music at Barnswallow Books
thread.title_full: Halloween stories, music at Barnswallow Books

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Halloween stories, music at Barnswallow Books
text:
Halloween stories, music at Barnswallow Books Oct 23, 2015 Miners Creek will turn around and fill the Barnswallow Barn with music on Halloween. 
Rockport — On Halloween — Saturday, Oct. 31 — Barnswallow Books will host another great barn event, this time featuring bluegrass band Miners Creek and storyteller "Pirate" John Bullock. 
The community — costumed or not — is invited to celebrate the holiday from 5 to 7:30 p.m. in the downtown Barnswallow Books, 166 Russell Ave., across from the library and adjacent to the former CMCA location. 
Miners Creek will also be celebrating its second birthday while playing the band’s distinctive take on bluegrass — integrating traditional with ‘60s folk revival, Latin, Appalachian, classic rock and old timey tunes, plus a sprinkling of jug band. The Rockport-based band features three members of the Randolph family (Whitney, Resa and their daughter Emily), joined by Peter Proeller on claw hammer banjo. 
“Pirate” John will kick the evening off at 5 p.m., performing a half hour of spooky tales from Edgar Allan Poe, Washington Irving and Maine native Ruth Moore. Miners Creek will then take to the floor at 5:30 p.m. with a 45-minute set of music. The storyteller will return for a longer performance, and Miners Creek will wind up the show with a second set of music. 
Barnswallow Books is offering the party as a free community event; there will be light fare, yummy cake, coffee and cider. Everyone is invited to come early to browse the curated shelves of old and new books of this honest-to-goodness community bookshop, in the heart of Rockport village. Attendees will want to be dressed warmly and in their seats by the time “Pirate” John takes the barn floor at 5 p.m. 
For more information about the event, email minerscreekband@gmail.com. Barnswallow’s main bookshop will remain open all year and feature a small café, beginning in mid-November. 
Courier Publications’ A&E Editor Dagney C. Ernest can be reached at (207) 594-4401, ext. 115; or dernest@courierpublicationsllc.com.
